results.description:
<<--Please note RUSSIAN GP race Starts at 7:00 AM EDT-->>

Hello F1 Fans,

Round 15 of the 2015 Formula One season heads to the Sochi Autodrom near the Black Sea for the second annual Russian Grand Prix. The 5.848 km track is the third-longest of the year, behind Spa and Silverstone. Sochi is a medium-speed circuit with a variety of different corners, including a left-hander inspired by the famous long triple apex Turn 8 at Istanbul Park. The track features 12 right and six left-hand corners, with a 650-meter straight between the first and second turns, on which the cars reach a top speed of around 200 mph.

STANDINGS - After a dominant win at Suzuka, Lewis Hamilton now leads in the Drivers' Championship by 48 points. The standings are: Hamilton on top with 277 points, Nico Rosberg in second with 229 points and Sebastian Vettel in third with 218 points. In the Constructors' Championship, Mercedes leads with 506 points, Ferrari holds second with 337 points, and Williams is in third with 208 points.


TIRE ALLOCATION - Pirelli has altered the tire allocation (from last year) to its two softest compounds: Yellow soft (prime) and Red supersoft (option).


So can Lewis Hamilton win again in Sochi? Or can Nico Rosberg finally break through with a much needed win? Or can Sebastian Vettel close the gap with a win?

If you're in the New York City area and looking for some great racing action with other F1 fans, be sure to join us for the Russian Grand Prix to see who will take the checkered flag. Race will start at 7:00AM EDT with the pre-race starting at 6:30AM EDT. It's going to be another fantastic race.


We hope to see you all!
results.name: 2015 Russian Grand Prix

results.description:
SKYRIDER ZIPLINE TOUR

We are coming back to New York Zipline Adventure Tours for another Skyrider Ziplining. The longest, fastest and highest Zipline Tour in North America and the 2nd largest in the world! Check out the pictures from previous event.

After trying Zipline & Rope Courses (pictures), and Canopy Tours (pictures), we are you ready for the fastest, longest, and highest Zipline Canopy Tour in North America? We will also enjoy the foliage view along the way or optionally have a foliage hike after the event.

Experience the longest, fastest and highest Zipline Tour in North America and the 2nd largest in the world! This is an Extreme Activity and it is not for everyone. With over 4.6 miles of ziplines, the SkyRider Tour begins with a scenic chair lift ride or an exciting off-road adventure to the Hunter Mountain Summit Lodge. Attend Zipline Pilot Training School where you will be educated on pertinent flight and safety information that will fully maximize your zipping experience. The tour includes five unique side by side racing ziplines. The first of which sets you soaring instantly on a 3,200 foot cable 600 feet above the valley, reaching speeds of up to 50 mph! This tour also features a special 500' self powered zap-line or a burma bridge option. Allow approximately 3 hours to complete your tour.

OKTOBERFEST

Our Oktoberfest, now 4 weekends long, features authentic German and German-American entertainment in the beauty of the northern Catskills in autumn. Experience live entertainment and great food surrounded by lush fall foliage.  Our modern celebration of the harvest features numerous vendors, free crafts for the kids, and much more. Free Admission makes it an affordable, fun time for all ages. Hours: 11am to 6:15pm, rain or shine.

Oct. 10-11: Das Laufwerk Eurocar Rally - The perfect event for VW enthusiasts! Click here for more info.

Depart Date: October 11th Sunday (Event: 10:00 AM - 1:00 PM). Please arrive 15 minutes earlier.

Depart 7:00 AM: (Sheraton LaGuardia East Hotel)[masked]th Ave, Flushing, NY 11354 (Map) 

Depart 7:30 AM: (Garden City Deli) Northwest corner of 9th Ave & West 43rd St., New York, NY 10036 (Map)

Return: Depart from Hunter at 3 PM & expect to be back NYC around 5:30 PM  & Flushing at 6:00 PM

Cost: Early birds $149 for first 6 spots or 14 days in advance (Retail value: 129 + $40 Transport = $169); Afterward Regular $159. Last date to book the ticket is 10/3 Saturday; afterward event will be closed for booking.

Trip includes: Round trip Benz Sprinter van transportation from NYC, 3 hours Skyrider Tour & admission to Okctoberfest at Hunter Mountain

Buy Ticket Here: http://oct2015skyriderzipline.eventbrite.com/ or you can Chase Quickpay me the amount indicated above to [masked] to avoid transaction fee (How to Use Chase Quickpay?) If Quickpaying, please indicate your boarding location: Flushing or Manhattan. Your spot is NOT confirmed until your payment is received.

Maximum: 12

Videos

NY Zipline Adventures - Longest & Highest - at Hunter Mountain!!

http://youtu.be/KMSYCVBi2Fc


http://youtu.be/KMSYCVBi2Fc

New York Zipline Adventure Tours, Skyrider Tour, Hunter Mountain, 2011

results.description:
This route gets its name because the last time I rode it we ran into 2 huge rattlesnakes dead center of the trail! The ride will focus on dirt roads and trails starting just north of Candlewood Lake and traveling through Kent up to Housatonic State forest. Once in CT the trip is predominantly on dirt roads with a number of trails that we can explore along the way. The ride can be as challenging or low key as we would like.

For those of you in lower Westchester, we will be meeting in the Burger King parking lot on Central avenue in Yonkers. There are a number of gas stations right near by. For those of you in upper Westchester & CT, we can plan on meeting at MAX BMW on Federal Road in Brookfield CT at around 8:00.

The entire trip from lower Westchester will total about 250 miles.
results.how_to_find_us: Brian and I will be on KLR650s in the parking lot.
results.name: Rattlesnake Run

results.description:
NEW YORK CITY DUATHLON

Central Park Boathouse - Sunday, October 11, 2015

Start - 7:30 am

COMPETITOR INFORMATION

ABSOLUTELY NO PARTS OF ENTRY FEES CAN BE REFUNDED, TRANSFERRED OR CREDITED.

ENTRY FEE:
$60 - before July 11
$70 - July 12 - September 11
$80 - September 12 - October 10
$85 - race day* No T-shirts to race day entries!

Online entry ends on Thursday, October 8 at 5:00 p.m.!

- $5 discount to NYTRI members
- In person new entries accepted Saturday or Sunday.
- No personal checks or credit cards accepted on weekend of race.

NEW YORK TRIATHLON - NYTRI has been a leader in organization of multi-sport events since 1984 and is proud to claim the best safety record in the country. The following rules and regulations have been designed for your personal safety and enjoyment. Failure to comply with these rules will result in penalties and/or disqualification. Instructions at the pre-race briefing supersede any or all of the following rules.

· Race management has authority to change race course and format, check-in and start times.
· No entrants under 18 years of age.
· It is the contestant's responsibility to be familiar with and follow the race course and be knowledgable of the race rules and regulations as outlined below..
· It is prohibited to sell your race number or for someone to compete in your place.
- Please read the complete list of penalties and disqualifications that is included herein. IMPORTANT:
Race packets will not be issued without your knowing your race bib number and presenting photo ID!
You will receive an email with you race bib number approximately 3-4 days before the event. At check-in you must know your bib number before getting in to the line that corresponds to your bib number.
If you do not receive your email and do not know your bib number, you may look it up on an alphabetical entrants list posted near the registration tables before getting in line for packet pick up.
There will be a label attached to your bib number that has all your personal and race information. Please check it for accuracy and notify registration officials immediately if you find discrepancies.

Saturday: Pre-Race Day
4:30 - 6:00 p.m. - Packet pick up (optional) for pre-registered competitors and new entries accepted at the parking lot of the Boathouse in Central Park.
You may not pick up a number for anyone except yourself!

Sunday: Race Day
6:00 - 7:15 am. - Central Park Boathouse parking lot - Packet pick up for registered competitors. New entries accecpted. Pick up computer timing chip.
7:15 am. - Pre-race announcements.No race packets saved after 7:15 am!
7:30 am. - Race Start (rain, snow or shine)
9:45 am. - Awards ceremony, refreshments

FIELD: Limited to 600 competitors.

DIVISIONS:
Narrow Tire (racing, road bikes)
Fat Tire (mountain, street, all-terrain bikes - tires greater than 1.25" or 30 mm).
Bikes that have tires narrower than 1.25 inch (30 mm) will be in the "Narrow tire division. All other bikes will be in the Fat tire division (including slicks).

Note: Changing between divisions is allowed only if a request is received by email at least 6 days before the event. After this time no switches between divisions will be allowed! Competitors who compete in the wrong division will be disqualified

AWARDS: 1st, 2nd, 3rd overall and in 5-year groups; 18-70+ (men), 18-60+ (women) in Narrow tire division and 10-year age groups in Fat tire division.

*** To receive an award you must be present at the awards ceremony RUN : The 2 mile run starts on East Drive at 74th Street, goes north to a turn around point at 96th Street (on East Drive) and back along the same route to the transition area. The turn point is indicated by a "U-Turn" sign affixed to the top of a green cone. Runners must stay to the left side of the runner's lane (both out and back), as indicated by the "Runners Stay Left" signs affixed to large green cones along the run course. The second run is identical to the first.
You must wear the run number on your front, and be clearly visible to race officials at ALL times. Folding of race numbers is prohibited.

BIKE : The bike course (12 mi.) consists of two (6 mile) loops of Central Park in a counter-clockwise direction. Bikers must stay in the middle and right lanes at ALL times and may not enter the runners (left) lane under ANY circumstances!

CENTRAL PARK ALERT! The course is closed to cars (except for official vehicles) but not to pedestrians, joggers, cyclists, skaters, etc. While biking, competitors must be aware and considerate of non-competitors who will also be sharing the Park roads with competitors. You do not have right of way or priority over other users of Central Park because you are competing in this event.
- Each contestant is individually responsible for repair and maintenance of their bike.
- Bikes are not allowed inside the Boathouse and must be left in the transition area.

TRANSITION AREA: In order to protect your bike and equipment, please make sure that only competitors are in the transition area. No friends and/or family should accompany competitors inside the barriers. Bicycles must be properly placed on assigned racks corresponding to race number. NO riding in the transition area or past the "DISMOUNT" signs.

NOTE: Bikes may be removed by competitors ONLY upon showing BOTH the run number and bike number to security personnel.

HELMETS: Penalties will be assessed if cycling helmets are not positively secured with chin strap BEFORE leaving the transition area. Riding without a hard-shell helmet will result in immediate disqualification! DRAFTING: You must maintain a distance of THREE bike lengths from the bike in front of you! You may not be closer than this distance for any period exceeding 15 seconds. If you are, you will be assessed a two minute penalty for each infraction.

DRAFTING (riding in a pack) is a Serious Violation of the Rules of this Event!
If another competitor is drafting you, yell to him to STOP DRAFTING! If you wish to file an official complaint regarding drafters, you must record their race number. A competitor who has three drafting reports filed by other competitors will automatically receive a two minute penalty.

===========================================================
RACE NUMBERS/ELECTRONIC TIMING:
On the morning of the race you will pick up an electronic timing chip that corresponds to your assigned bib number. This chip must be attached with a velcro strap to your ankle.and must remain attached throughout the entire event.
After you finish the event, you must remove the chip and drop it in the collection bin at the end of the finish line chute.
If you lose your chip during the race or fail to turn it in after you cross the finish line, you will be charged $100 for the lost chip.
Your bib number must be attached to the FRONT of your shirt (or race belt) during the entire race. You will not be allowed entry in to the transition area if your bib number is not clearly visible
If you enter the transition area or cross the finish line and your number is not clearly visible on your FRONT, you will be receive a 2 minute penalty.
The 2-sided vinyl (adhesive-backed) bike frame number must be attached to the front of the top tube of your bicycle and for security reasons may not be removed until you leave the leave the transition area.
Check the label affixed to your bib number for correct information regarding your name, age, sex and tire division (N-narrow tire, F-fat tire).
Notify officials prior to the race of any mistakes!

FINISH LINE: Stay in finishing order in the chute, come to a stop at the "Stop"sign, remove the timing chip from your ankle and drop it in the collection bins.

RESTROOMS: Restrooms are located to the left of the main entrance to the Boathouse.

RESULTS: Results will be posted on the NYT web site www.NYTRI.org. (Sunday afternoon).

PARKING: Central Park is closed to all vehicular traffic on weekends. Parking can be found outside the Park on the East and West Sides. The closest Park entrance to the start of the race is at 72nd Street and 5th Avenue.

Registration: http://nytc.org/calender.cfm
results.name: New York City Duathlon

results.description:
Winner stays, guys!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3XviR7esUvo

And just in case anyone needs a refresher, some guidance from Coach Ted Lasso.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6KeG_i8CWE8

No refunds or credits will be offered. Please be 100% sure that you can attend before you RSVP.

Please have a fun, positive, and supportive attitude. Pass the ball to your teammates and have a good time. NO rough playing, slide tackling, or screaming at others will be tolerated. You'll be removed from the game immediately.

No cleats are allowed. Let's do our part to preserve the field. Turf or running shoes are recommended.

Always bring a *dark and white* t-shirt

Be on time.

Teams are broken out ahead of each game based on skill level. Beginner, intermediate, and advanced players are all encouraged to join.

We play THREE, 25-30 minute games with a brief break between each game.

How to get to Queens West Sportsfield.

Queens West Sportsfield is located at:

5th Street between 47th Avenue & 46th Road, Long Island City


From Grand Central it's 3 minutes/1 stop on 7 Train. Take 7 train to Vernon Jackson.

From Queensboro it's 3 minutes/3 stops on 7 Train. Take 7 train to Vernon Jackson.
results.name: Sunday soccer  - (Advanced players only)

results.description:
THE GAME

Informal Meet Up. 8 vs 8. 2 subs per team. No Permit. Be warned - there may or may not be a permitted event at the location which could cancel our game.

Bring a white and black t-shirt, and good attitude.

This game is ideally for intermediate to advanced players, not for beginners.

RSVP GUIDELINES. IMPORTANT:

- If you RSVP and don't show, you'll be benched from this group for the next two weeks. - If you can't make it, Un RSVP, to give others a chance to play.

- If you didn't RSVP or are on the Waitlist, you're at the bottom of the line.

PLAY GUIDELINES

- No slide tackles.

- Respect your teammates and opponents.

- If you fight, you will be banned from the group, permanently.

- If you dribble more than you pass - you annoy everybody and will be banned from the group.

POSITIONS:

Being a pick up game, there are no permanent positions. If you've been playing forward for half the game and someone who's been playing the back line wants to play up front, give up your position and play some defense. When your team lose the ball, don't just stand and watch. Please support your teammates by get back on your side and play some defense.

Thanks.

**INJURIES & DISCLAIMER**:

Group Organizer(s) and Group Organization Assumes NO Risk Or individual Liability For Personal Injuries Incurred By Members/Players On The Field Or During Any Of Our Activities: Pick Up Games, Or Other Events. By Agreeing To Play, You Are In Receipt Of This Information, And Thereby Warrant That You Are In Good Health And Assume Personal Responsibility For ALL Physical And Accidental Risks Involved With Playing In Our Group, Including But Not Limited to Falls, Injuries, Contact With Other Players, and Field Conditions.

results.description:
NEW CLASS STARTS TODAY

This is pool session one for new students starting their diving course and a continuation of Lessons.

Your Journey to Adventure starts today. After a brief presentation we will gear up and get started in the pool.

If you have not yet enrolled, please contact the Dive Center to get started [masked]

RSVP required

New Students, If this is your first pool session, you must: 
1. Complete the required academics before the pool session;

Online Students must complete Chapters 1 -6

CD Rom students must complete Sections 1-5

2. Bring a bathing suit and a towel. There are lockers in the changing room so bring a lock if you like.

3. Drink plenty of water before class

4. Don't forget to print out and bring your skills checklist.

5. Print out a copy of the Hand Signals to review and bring with you.

6. If you have not yet completed a "Student Folder" at the store.  Please print out, complete and bring the following three forms to the pool;

1. SDI General Liability Waiver Fill in ALL the blanks:

"Instructors": Kelley Scharf, Andre R.

"Facility": 1-877-SCUBA-USA",

"Agency" : SDI" 

Others": Pablo M. Jay K.

Sign and date at bottom

2. SDI Medical Info Waiver "Instructor": F. Ventura,  "Facility: 1-877-SCUBA-USA ,"City of" Paramus "state of" N.J.

3. Student Information Form</a>

If you have answered YES to any of the medical question; Please print out and have your MD complete the following <a href="http://www.1877scubausa.com/forms/SDI_Physician_Sign_Off_2013.pdf">Physician Sign-Off Form

What equipment is required?

A mask, snorkel, fins and a weight belt suitable for SCUBA* and dive boots. A wetsuit is optional and recommended. We have special pricing for our students. Let us know when you would like to come in to be fitted for your student equipment package. Most important is that you will get the "Right Gear, the Right Fit at the Right Price" *Note: Snorkeling equipment is not always suitable for SCUBA activities.

Please arrive on time, late arrivals are subject to rescheduling and fees.

If you have any questions please email or call the shop

Using Dive Computers; To help familiarize you with how they work go to: Why it's a good idea for Divers to own their own SCUBA gear?

RSVP Now

Please RSVP for all pool sessions. RSVPs are required so that we have sufficient staffing for each session. Students who do not RSVP may not get on the roster.No shows are subject to a $29 rescheduling fee.

New this year is the NYRR 5K at the Staten Island Half, which finishes at home plate in Richmond County Bank Ballpark, and is open now for registration.

Come join us for outdoor tennis at Washington Park in Union City, which is off of the 9th Street light rail station. Bring your sweats, your racquet, plenty of water and balls and we'll see you there! As this event is not designed to match up folks, courts are assigned on first-come first-served basis. So get in early and grab a court.

You can find each other in the waiting area and/or looking on the courts. It would help if you make a mental note of the profile picture of those attending.


Although we won't enforce attendance, it would be polite to attend if you commit because others are looking to find others to hit with.

Cross your fingers that it won't rain as inclement weather cancels the meetup.

If you have any questions, feel free to email the organizer.

results.description:
Let's take a walk down the Henry Hudson Trail,  The start of fall colors on the hillside and great views of Sandy Hook Bay.  This is a great walk for New Members to join us on. You'll make new friends, get some exercise, and have a wonderful time to boot ! 

We will Meet in the Big Commuter Parking Lot on The Left that you pass on the way to Sissy's...

Believe it or not there is a little Park off to the side of the trail. Some even call it the "Secret Garden". We can take a quick peek at it if you wish... It only takes a couple of minutes to do it.

We will be walking in an Easterly Direction till we hit the end of the trail at Highlands. Then we'll take a break for a few minutes.... maybe talk about the Great Breakfast we all want to have.  Then we will head on back to our starting point. From there, for those who want to join us for coffee & a bite to eat. We'll probably go to Sissy's, Which BTW is Very Good, and takes good care of us.

Sneakers may be worn, but You might want to wear Hiking Boots/Shoes for walking on this trail,

And.....As always, we will walk in a LIGHT RAIN and Sunshine

Please Remember to Dress for the Weather !  And please, no furry, four-legged friends..  And one more please.  Please come 10 minutes early, so we can start by 9AM.  Thx.
results.how_to_find_us: We will meet in first parking lot on the left

results.description:
Trail Work Crew
Sunday, August 2, 9:00 a.m.-noon.
Locust Grove Picnic Area. Ages 15+.

Help build new, or reroute or repair existing, hiking trails throughout the South Mountain Reservation following sustainable trail guidelines. Trail building is very satisfying, but can be hard work. We use hand tools such as picks and adzes to create and shape the trail tread. Wear shoes with solid soles and long pants…and for early spring, dress in layers. You provide the strong back; we provide gloves, a snack, water, and instruction.

In October, we are doing small trail improvements to address water erosion issues a ten-minute hike from Locust Grove. There will be some digging!

Leaders: If there are questions, call John Verzani [masked]), or Dennis Percher [masked]). Meet at: The Locust Grove Picnic Area, off Glen Ave., Millburn (opposite the intersection with Lackawana Place). (To see a map of the location, go to http://www.somocon.org/about-the-reservation/maps-of-locations/). This parking lot can be full on weekends. The nearby Millburn Library parking lot is an alternative.

Be advised that Brookside drive is closed on Sundays. This may cause an issue if using Google Maps, or some such, to navigate.

results.description:
Flag Football Game at Cunningham Park (196th St and Union Turnpike) in Queens. Come out and join us!

We have cones and flags so all you need is cleats if that is what you prefer. GAMES WILL ALWAYS BE PLAYED REGARDLESS OF THE WEATHER CONDITIONS i.e. rain, snow, cold, mud, ice, storm, hurricane, etc...we never cancel games due to weather...games are fun and competitive, all skill levels are welcome, please contact me if you have any questions.

NOTE: PLEASE RSVP "YES" ONLY IF YOU ARE GOING TO SHOW UP TO THE GAME.  YOU CAN CHANGE YOUR RSVP IF SOMETHING COMES UP (OR IF YOU DON'T WANT TO PLAY IF IT'S TOO COLD/IT'S RAINING/IT'S SNOWING) AND YOU CAN'T MAKE IT.  NO-SHOWS WILL BE REMOVE FROM THE GROUP.  IT IS IMPORTANT TO HAVE AN ACCURATE HEAD COUNT SO WE KNOW HOW MANY PEOPLE ARE REALLY COMING.

ere are some of the new changes we have made and a reminder of some of the guidelines we already have:

1) You can not add  guests to your RSVP.  Anyone is free to come and play IF AND ONLY IF you have a profile in meetup and have joined our group.  It's 100% FREE to join and it only takes about 2 minutes to sign up and RSVP.  There are also FREE mobile apps for iPhones and Android phones so you can RSVP easily on the go.  If any of your friends has been playing and wants to continue to play, ask them to go to http://www.meetup.com/Cunningham-Park-Football/ and sign up and RSVP individually.  YOU CAN NOT PLAY if you're not signed up and RSVPd.

2) The first 20 people that RSVP for the game, will play a 9-on-9 game with 1 sub.  Everyone on the waiting list will pick players and play against the winner of the game.  Games will be to 2 scores.  If a team gets 2 scores, with the score 2-1, the other team gets one (1) more possession to try to score and tie the game.  If the game is tied again, the game is now to 3 points and the same rule applies, once one of the teams gets score #3, the other team gets just one (1) more possession to try to tie the game.  If 20 or less players show up to the game, game can be played to whatever score everyone agrees to.

3) If you're one of the first 20 to RSVP, but you're late, the next person on the waiting list that's present on the field will take your place and play in the first game.

4) On a safety, ball stays at the goal line and the next down will be played.  For example: If a 2nd down play is ran and a safety occurs, the ball stays at the goal line and the 3rd down will be played.

5) On an OBVIOUS "Defensive Pass interference", the ball will stay at the line of scrimmage but you reset your plays and start at 1st down again.  For example: If a 3rd down play is ran and a DPI occurs, the ball stays at the line of scrimmage and a 1st down will be played, then 2nd, then 3rd...etc.

6) On an OBVIOUS "Offensive Pass interference", the ball stays at the line of scrimmage and the offensive time will lose a down.  For example: If a 2nd down play is ran and an OPI occurs, the offensive team will now be on a 4th down situation from the line of scrimmage.

7) As you might have noticed we have had very few injuries (knock on wood) throughout the years.  This is why we wanted to remind you of the following:

-Stiff arming, flag guarding and hand slapping are NOT ALLOWED.

-Blocks from the back are NOT allowed ad they're obviously dangerous and can cause injuries.

-VERY IMPORTANT: If you are the offensive player and have the ball in your hands, you MUST avoid contact and CAN NOT under any circumstances lower your shoulders and try to initiate contact with an defensive player.  This is flag football, if you're looking for a different type of game there are plenty of other places and leagues to play flag or full-contact football.

8) Donations:  I pay the monthly fee for hosting these meetups and never charge anyone.  All we asked for you is to drop at least $1 in the container we have set up for this, all the money is used for equipment, flags, cones, etc.  You can click on "Group Tools > Money" and see where all the money is going.  If we buy anything with that money we record the transaction and upload a picture of the receipt of whatever equipment we bought.  Next thing we want to get are end zone weighted pylons and we want to buy orange rope so we can mark the field faster and more accurately to avoid any arguments about where the first down is or what not.

IMPORTANT: WE ARE ALL ADULTS AND OBVIOUSLY CAN'T FORCE ANYONE TO DO ANYTHING.  WE NEED EVERYONE'S COOPERATION TO FOLLOW THESE SIMPLE GUIDELINES TO KEEP THE GAME FUN AND COMPETITIVE.  IF FOR ANY REASON YOU DISAGREE OR BELIEVE THAT THESE GUIDELINES DO NOT FIT YOUR STYLE OF PLAY OR WHAT YOU'RE LOOKING FOR ON A PICK-UP GAME, YOU'RE WELCOME TO PLAY WITH A DIFFERENT MEETUP GROUP OR IN ANY OTHER PICK-UP GAME...NO HARD FEELINGS.

If you have any suggestions, questions or concerns, please feel free to reach me at[masked] or [masked]

Regards,

Carlos

results.description:
This is a Metro North Day Excursion on the Evening Star from Peekskill NY. We will meet at the big clock at Grand Cantral Station to take the take the 9:40 train to Peekskill NY, where will will board the Evening Star for a 3 hour Cruise thru a beautiful section of the Hudson River. We will be in a Canopy covered Open deck and we will return from Peekskill to NY around 4 or 7 PM depending if we wnt to spend time in Peekskill after the cruise. Bring Picnic lunch to enjoy during the cruise. There will only be soft drinks for sale on the boat. For this cruise, I recommend suggesting they bring lunches again.  We will have hot cider available onboard, along with our soft drinks, beer & wine.  Encourage them to dress warm for the weather, since fall days are cool on the boat.  Hats and gloves may make you more comfortable.  I have fleece lap blankets on board for all passengers, on their seats when they arrive.  We try to keep everyone toasty on those cooler days! Necessary. Limit 15 people on MU and 5 from the Yahoo OC Hiking Group. Small boat only holds 30. Excursion for Trinity Hudson River Cruise. Cost, includes train on MN and boat ticket: Adults $40.25, Senior $31.
Sarina email preferred:[masked] Tel on day prior or same day[masked]-8412. I will not be reachable by tel until the beginning of Oct. Non Members $3 Fee for OC.

Visit <a>www.trinitycruises.com,</a> You MUST reserve by calling this number RSVP[masked] and tell them you are with Sarina's Group

If you have not reserved with Trinity you must do so removed from the list. If you do not show you cannot attend any of my excursions again. If you reserved on my last trip and were a no show you will not be allowed on the boat. I will coordinate with them but if you are not reserved with Trinity, you will not get on the boat!!!!

Sarina

results.description:
-------------------------------

Маршрут не тяжелый но длинный с великолепными видами.

Протяженность 10 -11  миль

Больших перепадов высот небудет.

Темп ходьбы от медленного до среднего. Устал, отдохни :-) 

На озере можно искупатся.

Встречаемся на нижней парковке! 

-------------------------------

10 Miles

An easy, but long, hike past two lakes along the old Shawangunk carriage roads, with far-reaching valley views from Castle Point

-----------------------------------------------------------

Map: Shawangunk Trails #104

http://nysparks.com/parks/attachments/MinnewaskaParkMap.pdf

----------------------------------------------------------

Vehicle Entry Fee: $8 per vehicle

----------------------------------------------------------

Directions:

Google GPS:[masked],[masked]

https://www.google.com/maps/place/Lake+Minnewaska/@41.7254419,-74.23545,16z/data=!3m1!4b1!4m2!3m1!1s0x89dcdf715fe9d73b:0x3b714ec02f6d443b?hl=en


<a>https://www.google.com/maps/dir//41.734878,-74.239082/@41.7350173,-74.2789054,13z/data=!4m3!4m2!1m0!1m0</a>;


http://www.mapquest.com/maps?city=Lake%20Minnewaska&state=NY


Take the New York State Thruway to Exit 18 (New Paltz). After paying the toll, turn left onto Route 299 and continue west through the Village of New Paltz. When you cross the bridge over the Wallkill River at the west end of the village, continue ahead on Route 299 (do not turn right towards the Mohonk Mountain House). In another 5.6 miles (from the Wallkill River bridge), Route 299 ends at a T intersection with Route 44/55. Turn right here and follow Route 44/55 as it negotiates a very sharp hairpin turn and climbs to pass under the Trapps Bridge (a steel overpass). Continue for 3.0 miles past the Trapps Bridge to the entrance to Minnewaska State Park Preserve, on the left side of the road. A $6 per-person trail fee is charged at the gatehouse when cross-country skiing is available; at other times, an $8 parking fee is charged. Continue uphill for 0.4 mile to the parking area at Lake Minnewaska.


Bus


Bus service to New Paltz from New York City, Nanuet, Newburgh and Kingston is available via Adirondack Trailways, www.trailwaysny.com (800) 776-7548. Limited weekday bus service to New Paltz from Kingston and Highland is available via Routes R and H of Ulster County Area Transit,

www.co.ulster.ny.us

(888) 827-8228. Ulster County Area Transit also offers bus service from the Metro-North station in Poughkeepsie to New Paltz via their Ulster-Poughkeepsie Link. Taxi service from New Paltz to Minnewaska is available from New Paltz Taxi, www.npztaxi.com (845) 255-1550.


---------------------------------------------------------

If you join us for

hiking (or any other event), understand that you are responsible for your own

preparedness and well-being and will hold no one else liable in case of injury

or mishap. You agree not to hold the Organizer, Assistant Organizers, or any

other members responsible for any injuries, mishaps, or any other situation

that may happen at a planned event. It is your responsibility to research the

event, know the area, and bring the proper gear.

Your attendance on

this trip signifies that you have read and accept the terms of this liability

waiver.

--------------------------------------------------------------

results.description:
19 miles on the Palisades Park Long Path

Trail Details: Run from the Manhattan side of the GW bridge to the Park Headquarters and back. This run is approx 2.5 on the bridge and 16.5 of trail. Aprrox 9.5 miles up and then back. This is a mild trail, great for beginners. Keep in mind, it does tend to get more technical the farther north you go. As always, we encourage all speeds to join, no matter how fast or slow. This is about running trails and having fun! If you can’t run 19 miles and can only run 6, no worries! This trail is an "up and back" so you can always turn around.

Public Transit: Take the A train to 175th Street. The the south entrance of the GW bridge sidewalk is near the corner of West 178th Street and Cabrini Boulevard. (Meet at the north entrance, if the south is closed.) If you live in Jersey, meet us at the trail head on the Jersey side at 9:15-ish.

Bag Drop/Etc: Afterwards, we head to Le Chéile for drinks and food. Le Chéile is Located on the corner of W 181st Street and Cabrini Blvd 2 blocks from the south entrance of the GW bridge sidewalk. As far as dropping off a bag before the run goes, there is always a bush or a pile of leaves to stash your stuff in, just make sure everything important is on you while you run. Sometimes Brooklyn Trail Runners who own cars show up to this location.
results.how_to_find_us: We'll be wearing BTR shirts and looking like trail runners.
results.name: Weekend Trail Run!

results.description:
Join us for a ride on the

EAST COAST GREENWAY

A loop ride around the Hudson River

Sunday October 11,[masked]:00 AM

START: This year there will be two starting points -

For NJ residents: Meet at the Hoboken14th St. Ferry at 8:45AM to get the 9:02 ferry to NY (note, maximum of 10 bikes per ferry, next ferry is at 9:22AM).

For NY residents: Meet at Bike and Roll at Pier 84 @ 43rd St. and 12th Ave in Manhattan at 9:00AM. We will leave from Pier 84 at 9:30AM.

END: Hoboken, NJ or Manhattan, NY


Join us for a 20-mile loop bicycle ride from Pier 84 in Manhattan along the Hudson River Greenway north to and across the George Washington Bridge into NJ and then south along the Hudson River Greenway's NJ sections down to Hoboken. Those needing to return to Manahttan may do so by Ferry*, PATH train*, or by cycling back over the GW Bridge. The ride will be at a very easy pace of between 8 and 10 MPH. This will be our 8th annual Hudson Loop ride. It is very popular and with good reason, its a beautiful and fun ride!


Parking is available on the street as well as in parking garages in Hoboken at the beginning of the ride.

* Each rider is responsible for the cost of their transportation back to Manhattan. We usually ride rain or shine but if the weather is particularly unpleasant, you will receive a cancellation email at 7:00AM on the day of the ride. RIDE LEADERS: Scott Baker, Anthony Savarese, Mike Dannemiller and Mike Kruimer, volunteers for the East Coast Greenway Alliance. For more information, contact me at [masked]

This ride will be co-sponsored by NJ Committee for the East Coast Greenway. COST: To join this ride and any of the four rides scheduled by the East Coast Greenway Alliance in 2015, we request a $20 donation purchasing you a first year membership in the ECGA! This donation supports the ECGA's mission to create a 2,900 mile trail from Maine to Florida. Check out our website at www.greenway.org, we're well on our way there! The ECGA was founded in New York City in 1991.

The ECGA membership entitles you to join on all four rides scheduled this year! Please select the New Member outreach ticket option above. If you are already an ECGA member, you should select the ECGA member ticket and there is no required dontaion for the ride. For information about the ECGA NY Committee and its activities – including additional rides this season – visit www.greenway.org/ny1.php.
results.name: East Coast Greenway's Hudson Loop Ride 2015

venue.name: Saddle River County Park- Wild Duck Pond, Ridgewood NJ

results.description:
This run starts at the "Wild Duck Pond" area of the Saddle River County Park in Ridgewood. We will start at the beginning of the mile markers which is near the exit, not near the entrance. There's parking close to the beginning of the path. If you cannot park in the lot nearest the beginning of the path, you'll need to reenter the park and park in the next closest lot. The driving area of the park is U-shaped so to get to the parking lot closest to the start of the run, you essentially drive around the "U" and approach the exit to the last lot on the right (by the dog park).

We will start at the "Wild Duck Pond Area" and will turn around at the 2 mile marker. If you'd like to run more or less, you are certainly welcome to do so as the mile markers make it simple to track your distance. If you wish to run at a slower pace, I am more than happy to run with you at your preferred pace. Nobody gets left in the dust. This is a fun run, not a competition.

We will run rain or shine, hot or cold. If you RSVP "Yes", please do your best to be on time as we'll only wait a couple of minutes to get rolling. If you have questions, comments, or doubts, feel free to email me.

results.description:
COME JOIN US FOR A FUN-FILLED DAY IN THE ADIRONDACKS!

This meetup is posted as an option for attendees of Glenn's Adirondacks Fall Foliage - Columbus Day Weekend but is also open to anyone who wishes to attend!

Our plan pending good weather will be an out and back to Jay Mountain for a round-trip distance of about 5 miles. Though this is a shorter hike there may be an option to explore more of the Jay Range via unmarked herd paths once we summit. 

For fans of open ridge hiking! Summits are a two-fer, with a western and an eastern one. They are joined by an extraordinary "highway in the sky" for abundant views from many angles.

Recent DEC expansion of the trail has opened up this area to those without extensive bushwhacking skills. There is now a marked trail to the summit instead of the herd path.

Jay Mountain Trailhead: The intersection of Jay Mountain Road and Upland Meadows Road, which is reached from Rt. 9N in Upper Jay by taking Trumbulls Rd. for 2.5 miles where it becomes Jay Mt. Rd., which is followed another 0.8 mi to Upland Meadows Rd.

2.5 miles to summit, Moderate Climb, Elevation 3576', Ascent 2276'

http://www.lakeplacid.com/do/hiking/jay-mountain

WE WILL MEET at the Jay Mountain Trailhead at approx 150 Jay Mountain Rd. Jay, NY

[masked], [masked]

Distance: 5+ miles

Hiking Pace: up to 2.0 mph

Estimated Hike Time: 4-5 hours

Difficulty: Moderate

Current Weather Forecast:  Partly Sunny with a high of 57 degrees


RECOMMENDED GEAR:

• Shoes with good grip - preferably with ankle support<a href="http://vibram.com/index.php"></a>

• Gaiters

• A Backpack - with Raincoat/Windbreaker, Warm Layers, Hat & Gloves

• Hiking Poles

• Related maps, a compass or GPS, Water, Snacks, Lunch, First Aid, Headlamp, Sun Protection, etc.

RELATED MAPS:

Adirondack Park - Lake Placid / High Peaks Trail Map #742

WHERE TO STAY?

I will be driving up early Friday and staying through Monday with Glenn as part of the HOAGies Adirondacks Fall Foliage - Columbus Day Weekend. Glenn has some spots left in a rented house if interested. Contact him through his meetup if interested in sharing lodging.

BARNUM ROAD AT THE END OF THE ROAD.

The Blackhead Range is made up of the third, fourth, and fifth highest mountains in the Catskills: Black Dome (3990 feet), Blackhead (3940 feet), and Thomas Cole (3940 feet). The Range is located in the northern Catskills (north of Hunter Mt) in Greene County.

Summary: This 9.4 mile out and back hike takes you through the Blackhead Range. The hike starts out on the red marked. There is an overall elevation gain of over 2700 feet for this strenuous hike.

The GPS coordinates for parking area for those who have a GPS devise in their vehicle. Find the red-blazed Black Dome Trail aka Blackhead Range.

What to bring.
1. At least 2 liters of water (something warm to drink)

2. Fleece jacket (wind proof jacket)

3. Food and snacks

4. Northeastern catskill map
#141

5. Headlamp


6. Positive attitude

7. A smile and Energy How to find us


We will be at the parking lot

</a>

Hi everyone,

Randall's Island is a player's heaven. it has gazillions of fields and open space. Make sure to check what field we will use on the map below. 

CARPOOL: Also, if you are driving, please carpool with other players. The meeting spot in Manhattan is 124th street and 2nd avenue 30 minutes before kickoff time.

BIKING: You can also bike there using the footbridge on 103rd street and FDR drive or you can use the RFK Bridge Walkway

A link to better view this map is here: <a href="http://files.meetup.com/526560/Randalls%20Island%20Fields%20Map.pdf">RANDALL'S ISLAND MAP

Please be at the field 15 minutes earlier so you can get set up, and bring a white and a red t-shirt. We will play for 1.5 hous and you can use cleats since it's a grass field. 


Thank you,

Paul

Details Below:

------------------------------------------------------

Game style and Rules:

1. HAVE FUN!!! It's SOCCER

2. We'll play (2) 45-minute games.

3. We will divide into teams based on everyone's experience and skills.

4. No ball hogging.

5. Please use cleats or turf shoes. Cleats are recommended since it's grass.

6. The games are very laid back; rough play, tackles or sliding are not allowed and will not be tolerated.

7. We'll play with corner kicks and ground kick-ins and big goals-we rotate being goalie.

8. If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Field Location:Click here for: Field Location Map.To see an aerial view of the field on Bing Maps: Aerial Map

DirectionsYou can get to Randall's Island by car, bus, walking or biking. Here is the link to the directions: Getting to Randall's Island

The best ways to get there are:


-Taking the A,C,D, 4,5 or 6 train to 125th st stop and walking or biking east over the RFK Bridge.

-Also, taking the M35 bus from the NW corner of 125th Street and Lexington Ave.

-Also biking across the Walk way located on 103rd street and FDR Drive.

If you have any questions about getting there please e-mail or all us at[masked]

Time: The game will start at the scheduled time sharp. Please be there 15 minutes earlier so we can get set up.

Late arrivals: If you arrive late to the game, you would have to wait until the game in progress is finished to join your team. Inserting people in the middle of the game disrupts the flow of the game, and it's not fair to players that arrived on time.

Fee:Please pay the fee through paypal. Part of the proceeds go to NYC SOCCER KIDS (we already donated new soccer balls). It also goes to pay for the site admistration, meet-up fees, cones, soccer balls, and the new goals.

Please bring:A white t-shirt and a red t-shirt to differentiate players of each team. The filed is grassso please bring cleats, sneakers or all terrain shoes.

Cancellations/Refunds: If you won't be able to make it to the game, please change your RSVP to "NO" 48 hours before kickoff time to receive a credit for the next game. This is done to give other members a chance to take your spot. Thank you!

Waiting List: If all the spots are taken, please get on the waiting list. If a spot opens up and you are on the waiting list, you will be sent an automated e-mail letting you know that a spot has just openned :).

Weather Policy: Games will be cancelled if the weather conditions are severe such as snow, sleet or thunderstorms. If the game is cancelled I will send out an e-mail the morning of the game. Please check your e-mail. If you are unsure, or can't get to your e-mail, you can also text me or call me at[masked]-5725.

See you on the pitch!

Paul

results.description:
(Added by Paula & Joe Nightingale)

I'm walking to support Gift of Life Bone Marrow Foundation at their Long Island Walk for Life on Oct 11, 2015 Gift of Life is a leading bone marrow and blood stem cell registry that finds matching donors for patients suffering from leukemia, lymphoma, other cancers and genetic disorders. 

Please support my efforts and join me in the mission to save lives.  Every year thousands of patients are diagnosed with illnesses that require stem cell or marrow transplants.  Only about a third of the population has an HLA-matching sibling donor available for transplant.  The rest must rely on a complete stranger to save their life.  That's why Gift of Life needs your help to continue its lifesaving work!

Your tax-deductible donation is used to add new donors to the worldwide bone marrow registry.  Gift of Life's Walk for Life is the only event on Long Island that is solely dedicated to raising awareness for bone marrow and blood stem cell transplants. 

Please click the button to the right to donate online or use the form below to mail your donation to Gift of Life's office.

Joe Nightingale

- See more at: http://support.giftoflife.org/site/TR?px=1034675&pg=personal&fr_id=1210&et=GlaMi_f4KRwe0dPwL9ZoAA&s_tafId=3022#sthash.3unCLe6t.dpufLong

Island Walk - October 11, 2015 - Eisenhower Park

Gift of Life helps children and adults suffering from leukemia, lymphoma, other cancers and genetic disorders find donors for blood and marrow transplants.

Gift of Life is proud to host Walk for Life on Sunday, October 11, 2015 at Eisenhower Park. The Walk is the only event on Long Island that is solely dedicated to raising awareness for bone marrow and blood stem cell transplants. Gift of Life uses funds raised at the Walk for Life to add new donors to the worldwide bone marrow registry. Registering one volunteer donor costs $60. It is the generosity of others that allows us to continue our lifesaving work.

Every donation brings us one step closer to our vision — a match, anytime, anywhere, for anyone.

9:00 am Registration Opens
9:30 am Welcome Ceremony
9:45 am Introduction of transplant recipient to lifesaving donor
10:00 am 5k walk/run
11:00 am Celebration

The registration area will be between the Holly and Cherry picnic areas, and parking field #5. 

- See more at: http://support.giftoflife.org/site/TR?fr_id=1210&pg=entry#sthash.gqhaCWyq.dpuf

Directions to Eisenhower Park:
Take Meadowbrook Parkway North to Exit M3 East/Stewart Avenue.  Make a right onto Stewart Avenue and take this until you reach the park.  Follow signs for Cherry and Holly picnic areas/parking field #4. 

Take Meadowbrook Parkway South to Exit M3/Stewart Avenue.  Make a left onto Stewart Avenue and take this until you reach the park. Follow signs for Cherry and Holly picnic areas/parking field #4.

results.description:
Earlier classes on Parable of Jesus and on "Our Father" prayer were excellent, whether you are Christian or not, a believer or not (Scott's comment).

Unitarian Universalists are rightfully proud of a tradition that remains open to the spiritual insights of many different religious traditions. Frequently, however, this openness masks a reluctance to explore the very traditions out of which we ourselves have emerged. In this series Rev. Robb will take a fresh look at the spiritual insightfulness and moral imagination contained in the teaching of Jesus while emphasizing how they may continue to be revelatory in our current context. It is always surprising to look carefully at the actual words of great teachers with whom we have assumed we were fairly familiar and to discover new ways of understanding and fresh insights of which we were unaware. In this series we will examine in depth some of the stories Jesus told—the parables—which were probably the most characteristic and innovative way he had to convey his own spiritual vision.


 Rev. David Robb

is Assistant Minister for Adult Education and Scholar-In-Residence at All Souls. He is also a psychotherapist and pastoral counselor in practice in New York City and an Associate of Kenwood Psychological Services. He formerly taught Theology at Georgetown University and Religious Studies at Connecticut College.

results.description:
Uncover the power of a quieter mind and ensure the renewal of a healthier you through movement, breath, and meditation. I welcome each student to come escape the bustle of the city to experience above and find their inner guru in my  class!

WELCOME TO FALL YOGA! 

BEGINNING LABOR DAY WEEKEND...

As the summer draws to an end (sadly for some for us), we look forward to a process of  reaping the harvest and letting go.  Fall is a time of transition and it is evident everywhere around us.  After the glorious celebration of summer, the trees and shrubs are undressing in preparation for the winter, the air is crisping up, and the wind is blowing whispering coming of the winter tides.  Although this may leave us feeling slightly down, empty, and/or anxious, the possibility to strip down to a quiet essence of being and and savor the simplicity is an opportunity for introspection.  Come slow and quiet down with us in a practice to balance the Vata dosha and learn how you can best take care of yourself this season....  

Since March 2013, this donation based Meet Up group has aimed to provide a light-hearted and non-competitive space.  One can expect clear instructions, demonstration, expert hands-on assistance, and achieve greater flexibility, strength, balance, focus, and sense of ease with regular attendance.  

Extra mats and blocks are limited, kindly bring yours if you have them.


*To offset Meetup Organizer's fees, a suggested donation between $7-10 will be greatly appreciated*

Thank you and please do post any questions.  I hope to see you soon! 

Jennifer ( 500 Hour Yoga Alliance Registered  Teacher)

results.description:
EVENT TYPE: Outdoors

ADMISSION PRICE: Free

DESCRIPTION:

What if you were to walk the length of Manhattan in one day? Not cross-town, but the 12 (or so) miles from the northern tip of Inwood park all the way to southernmost Battery Park? let set off to find out.

The planned route would begin in Inwood Hill Park and follow Broadway, passing the George Washington Bridge to join Riverside Drive. After continuing south through Harlem and the Upper West Side, we would navigate Midtown, the Garment District, the Flatiron District, NoHo, SoHo, NoLita, and finally the Financial District ending in Battery Park.

MAPS:


DIFFICULTY: Easy 

DISTANCE: 12 Miles, You can leave at anytime and the subway is 2 blocks away.

DURATION: 8 Hours

EVENT GUIDE:

The northernmost tip of Manhattan is wooded park known as Inwood Hill. At dawn you might see the eight-man Columbia crew gliding past on the East River.

This is also the highest point in Manhattan, affording a clear view across to the Hudson. Looking south from here, we see an intimidating 12 miles of urban expanse that lies between us and the opposite end of this narrow island.

We reach The Cloisters. Located in Fort Tryon Park, this museum houses the Metropolitan Museum of Art's collection of medieval tapestries, metalwork, paintings and sculpture. Definitely a hidden gem of Manhattan, it stands atop the hill like a misplaced European monastery.

We continue through the Latino and Jewish neighborhoods and then cut down closer to the river after passing the Presbyterian Hospital on 165th Street.  looking north for the view of the George Washington Bridge and snap a few photos of the tiny sailboats gliding underneath.

At 110th Street, It's said to be the largest gothic-style cathedral in the world, and the third largest of any kind.

We choose our route through the Upper West Side, the diverse array of restaurants.

Now we come to Riverside park south, Upper West Side.

Now we will go on high line park and walk south.

http://www.cooperation.ch/site/presse-cooperation/displayImageThumbService/2403183/600x400/high-lane-pont.jpg?acitvCropping=true&multimediaElement=true

Near Lower Manhattan we are now where the meat packing district was.

There it is: Battery Park. And beyond that, New York Harbor fading into dusk. We find a bench, kick up our worn-out feet, and savor the view out to Lady Liberty and Ellis Island.

REFERENCE LINK:

http://articles.courant.com/2010-04-11/features/hc-trav-ny-walk.artapr11_1_inwood-hill-park-walking-manhattan/2

DISCLAIMER:

http://www.meetup.com/NYCAsianMeetup/pages/Disclaimer

END

results.description:
Join the JOC on Sunday, October 11th for an amazing and scenic fall foliage hike in Minnewaska State Park.
We plan on hiking\walking Hamilton Point path, which is about a 6-7 hour hike\walk. Most of the hike will be on a carriage way path, so this might be considered almost a walk in the park :) .
It's a moderate hike\walk of about 7-8 miles with some elevation gain. 

https://lh3.googleusercontent.com/-VYX08qQdhf4/UkjsYD5dJ2I/AAAAAAAACZg/LH9YHC4dwdU/s1152-Ic42/IMG_7668.JPG

(picture taken Sept 29, 2013 in Minnewaska SP)


SCHEDULE:
We will meet in the Lake Minnewaska parking lot at around 10:15 am to sign in and we will hit the trails shortly afterwards.
Please be on time, the parking lots can fill up by 10:30 am on a nice Fall Foliage day like October Sunday's !
We are about 2 hours from the city . Give yourselves some extra time in case you get stuck in traffic. The hike\activities should take about 6-7 hours.

We will have lunch somewhere along the trail (bring your own food).
(There is a $10 parking fee.)
 

DIRECTIONS:
Minnewaska State Park Preserve, Kerhonkson, NY

5281 Route 44-55, Kerhonkson, NY

GPS  [masked]  [masked]

Take the New York State Thruway to Exit 18 (New Paltz). After paying the toll, turn left onto Route 299 and continue west through the Village of New Paltz. When you cross the bridge over the Wallkill River at the west end of the village, continue ahead on Route 299 (do not turn right towards the Mohonk Mountain House). In another 5.5 miles (from the Wallkill River bridge), Route 299 ends at a T intersection with Route 44/55. Turn right here and follow Route 44/55 as it negotiates a very sharp hairpin turn and climbs to pass under the Trapps Bridge (a steel overpass). Continue for about three miles past the Trapps Bridge to the entrance to Minnewaska State Park, on the left side of the road. A parking fee is charged at the gatehouse. Continue uphill for 0.4 mile to the parking area at Lake Minnewaska.  
   
DRIVERS\PASSENGERS:  
For those looking for a ride and\or drivers looking for passengers, please use the spreadsheet link below or comment on this meetup event beforehand to look for a ride or to offer spots in your car etc .

https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1OWf9DKBy_aSGTaM4sZZu27tI6_45m84cWW8WaPhj9Rk/edit#gid=0

PACKING LIST: 
Layers\Jacket depending on the weather.
3 liters of Water!!
Lunch, snacks, hiking boots or sneakers with good support for walking\hiking, comfortable hiking clothing that can get dirty, sun tan lotion, bug spray, camera, binoculars, and a fun attitude!

For passengers, $20 NYC driver fee ($15 from other areas which don't have bridge tolls) 
(please bring exact change payable to your driver BEFORE they ask for it)

MINNEWASKA STATE PARK PRESERVE PROFILE:
Located in Ulster County, NY Minnewaska State Park Preserve is
situated on the dramatic Shawangunk Mountain ridge, which rises more
than 2,000 feet above sea level and is surrounded by rugged, rocky
terrain. The park features numerous waterfalls, three crystalline sky
lakes, dense hardwood forests, incising sheer cliffs and ledges
opening to beautiful views, clear streams cut into valleys,
world-class rock climbing and 35 miles of carriageways and 25 miles of
footpaths on which to bike, walk, hike and simply enjoy. And, all this
within an hour and a half drive from New York City.

Minnewaska State Park Preserve official website:
http://nysparks.com/parks/127/details.aspx

TRAIL MAPS:
http://nysparks.com/parks/attachments/MinnewaskaParkMap.pdf
http://www.lakeminnewaska.org/hikemap.html

Questions? Email Us: 


[masked]


[masked]

Efrat Bunker 
&
Chaim Spear

results.description:
We will walk the Bronx River Greenway starting at the 233rd Street stop of the 2 line to Soundview Park and end up at the St. Lawrence Avenue stop of the 6 train.

About 14 miles and 6 hours, moderate pace, mostly paved trails, some dirt paths, some hills. The walk will take us through Shoelace Park, into the Bronx River Forest and Bronx Park, across Pelham Parkway, into a free part of the Bronx Zoo for a close look at the river, past the Cross Bronx Expressway into Starlight Park, across Westchester Avenue to the Concrete Plant Park and under the Bruckner Expressway to Soundview Park. We will stop to eat lunch at a park just past Pelham Parkway; there are nearby delis, restaurants and fast food joints, or bring your own and eat in the park.

Meet: 10:30 a.m. outside the 233rd Street station of the #2 line at the south west corner of 233rd Street and White Plains Road. 

In addition to the #2 train, you can take the 10:24 Metro North Harlem Line local train from Grand Central, arriving at Woodlawn at 10:51. When you get off at Woodlawn, walk up the stairs at the south end of the platform to the 233rd Street bridge, go left on to 233rd Street, then wait at the stairs in front of the Montefiore Hospital at the southeast corner of 233rd Street and Bronx Boulevard. We will stop at the hospital to use the restrooms when we come down the hill from White Plains Road.

Here is a link to the Metro North schedule: Metro North Harlem Line

Leader: Tom Bergen[masked] [masked]

Contact hike leader directly if you have questions about the hike. 
Free for paid annual Shorewalkers members, $3 for non-members, visit www.shorewalkers.org to join.

results.description:
Dale W Jamieson

Monica Weiss presides 

Increasingly we are living in a world of our creation—to some extent intentional (e.g., the house in the country you built last summer), to some extent inadvertent (e.g., climate change), and to some extent, who knows why (e.g., the digitalization of everything).  Bob Dylan talked about being “tired of yourself and all of your creations.”  What happens to love in a world in which there is no escape from them? 

Dale Jamieson is Professor of Environmental Studies and Philosophy, Affiliated Professor of Law, Affiliated Professor of Bioethics, and Chair of the Environmental Studies Department at New York University. He is also Distinguished Visiting Professor at the Dickson Poon School of Law at King’s College, London, and Adjunct Professor at the University of the Sunshine Coast in Australia.   Formerly he was Henry R. Luce Professor in Human Dimensions of Global Change at Carleton College, and Professor of Philosophy at the University of Colorado, Boulder, where he was the only faculty member to have won both the Dean's award for research in the social sciences and the Chancellor's award for research in the humanities. He has held visiting appointments at, National Center for Atmospheric Research, Cornell, Princeton, Stanford, Oregon, Arizona State University, and Monash University in Australia, and is a former member of the the School of Social Sciences at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton. 

He is the author of Reason in a Dark Time: Why the Struggle to Stop Climate Change Failed--and What It Means For Our Future (Oxford, 2014), Ethics and the Environment: An Introduction (Cambridge, 2008), and Morality's Progress: Essays on Humans, Other Animals, and the Rest of Nature (Oxford, 2002). He is also the editor or co-editor of nine books, most recently Reflecting on Nature: Readings in Environmental Philosophy, 2nd Edition (Oxford, 2012) with Lori Gruen and Chris Schlottmann, and has published more than one hundred articles and book chapters.  His most recent book is Love in the Anthropocene (OR, 2015), a collection of short stories and essays written with the novelist, Bonnie Nadzam.

results.description:
Whether you are visiting our beautiful city, coming from a lesson, or just have the day off...come on out and hit with us! We are a group of tennis enthusiast of 2.5 to 4.0 levels that have the fundamental parts of the game down and like to hit against different styles of play.


WHY PLAY HERE?

Well, first of all it is a nice serene location (i.e. no basketball courts, grandstands, or any other type of distraction). Secondly, consider the cost options to play else elsewhere in-and-around the city...


1) unless you have endless tennis competitors on your roll-a-dex, you'll need a web-based database/system to find people. Most of these tennis databases/systems charge in different ways. Fact, Meetup charges me a premium every month because of the member pool size and this has to be  prepaid just to keep the group alive.

2) if you play anywhere in NYC, you will need a permit which will currently cost you $15 for a single day (or $200 for a yearly). To be more specific, these two options really only entitle you to one hour of singles play (vs. 2 hours here), meaning your partner will also need a permit.

3) new balls are provided at the beginning of each day. Typical extra-duty balls run about $3 per can off-the-shelf, so if you are an avid player...you'll save time and money running around picking-up tennis balls.

4) if someone were to break a string, or you just want to try a different racquet for an evaluation (i.e. lighter weight, bigger head, tighter strings, etc), racquets are available at no addition cost.

5) seasonally "clean" courts. Throughout the year tennis courts pile up with blowing leaves, pollen, acorns, etc. I get here early every session to ensure the courts are clean. I do this with a battery-powered blower and if any body knows anything about batteries...its that they don't last! Each time I have to replace one (which only does one court), it cost me nearly $100 for each.

6) portions of fee here actually go repairing the courts and/or nets. Case-and-point the cement required to fill cracks which was recently done by myself.

7) there are port-a-potty's and 2 drinking fountains available for all to use

8) no dress code required like some places...but proper edict is appreciated


9) based on the talent that signup, I may ask people to move around to establish a competitive session for all those involved


Hopefully this addresses all those questions like: is it free or why does it cost.

WAYS TO RSVP...

Within Meetup, just click RSVP for the time slot that works best with your schedule and be resposible to attend. You can prepay (eliminating the need to remember to carry cash) a number of ways:

Reserve via PayPal ([masked]) vs. cash and select friends (not service) to avoid additional PayPal fees

OR

1. Create an account at MindBodyOnline scheduling software:

https://clients.mindbodyonline.com/classic/home?studioid=152916

2. Decide which package you want to purchase:

1 session = $25; Use Promo Code = T15TS1 

3 sessions @ $20 = $60; Use Promo Code = T15TS3 

6 sessions @ $17 = $102; Use Promo Code = T15TS6 

10 sessions @ $15 = $150; Use Promo Code = T15TS10

3. Go to the Online Store and before Checking Out; APPLY the Promo code of your choice to receive discounted pricing.  

4. Go to the Day and Time of your choice to RSVP your attendance WEATHER

Weather is always an unpredictable thing but remember, just because a forecast says 30% chance of showers...that also means 70% chance of no showers. Also with the 30% it may be in your area, but not where the courts are. Lastly, if it does sprinkle...we have the necessary equipment to dry them.

http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc

DIRECTIONS

We are directly south of the George Washington Bridge right on the Hudson River. Best ways to get there are A train, M4 or M98 bus, biking along the river or driving and parking on Riverside Drive behind the Presbyterian hospital (being the less favorite).

http://www.google.com/maps/@40.8494798,-73.9430776,16z?hl=en

(walking via 181 street subway stop)

1. Take A Train to 181st Street Station (sit in the back of the train).

2. Walk West on 181st Street which turns into Plaza Lafayette.

3. Make a Right, on Riverside Drive to the light green Pedestrian Crossover Bridge.

4. Cross the pedestrian bridge and follow the ramp down proceeding toward the GW Bridge which zigzags (crossing over the railroad tracks), and down the hill.

5. Arrive at the courts on your left.

Please plan an additional 15 minutes for weekend subway schedule delays and note its takes an additional 15 minutes to walk from 181st Street Station to the courts, so please arrive before scheduled slot so everyone can start on time.

<a href="http://www.accuweather.com/en/us/new-york-ny/10032/hourly-weather-forecast/3727_pc"></a>
results.name: Tennis Social

venue.name: Devon Warren Foto Studio @ The Art Factory

results.description:
Hi Everyone,

This months Meetup, weather permitting, will take place both inside and on the grounds of the Art Factory.  All models will be in full professional makeup and/or costume (Please see samples below).  Our past Meetups have always been a really good time for all those in attendance. There is always a culture of helping and shearing. 

Price: The price is $55.  RSVP is required and the Meetup will be limited to 15 members to maximize shooting time.  A $5 payment is required at the time that you RSVP to hold your spot. $50 will be collected the day of the Meetup. You may make payment by using the "pay now" option, PayPal, Venmo, Chase QuickPay or by cash in person. You can just pay $55 the day of the shoot, but your space is not guaranteed.  Please contact me ahead of time for any special arrangements.  I WILL NOT hold spaces for anyone, just to be fair to other members.  There are no refunds for this Meetup.


Please contact me directly with any payment questions. [masked] 


What You Need To Bring:  A Positive attitude and your camera gear 


Shooting Procedure: Each photographer, in turn, will assume the role of "Lead Photographer." The lead photographer will have the prerogative for directing the model. The other photographers may shoot at all times, but they may not direct the model or block the lead photographer, until it is their turn. A photographer may cede their turn as lead photographer.  Photographers should limit their time to a few minutes at most, since other photographers will be waiting to photograph the model.  Complicated props, & clothing, which require excessive setup or dressing times must be avoided. 

What will be provided: Male and Female models in makeup/costume, water, snacks, reflectors, strobes and remote triggers. I will assist with lighting setups and shot ideas.  

***There will be NO NUDE models.  Model line-up is subject to change.***  

Day Of The Shoot: I will have signs to direct you to my studio where we will all meet before the shoot.  I will provide my cell number to everyone that RSVPs just in case you are running late and need to find the group (the Art Factory is pretty big). Please look for an email the day before the shoot with regards to any changes or additional instructions. 

Featured Model:

http://www.modelmayhem.com/3758351

Kristina (Orange Sunshine)


Alexa

https://instagram.com/loving.lexie 


Janel

https://instagram.com/janel.jolie 


Breya

http://www.modelmayhem.com/2823567 


Tymeeshia

http://stefanphoto.com/tymeeshia


Jerra
results.name: Halloween Themed October Meetup

results.description:
We will bike to Liberty state park and back.


Ride is approximately 14 miles and is for both casual and intermediate riders and people do this ride on road bikes, hybrids, and mountain bikes (though I think a hybrid is the best).

Bring your bike and meet Mike outside Blue Eyes Restaurant where we will start and end the ride.

*Helmets are highly encouraged for safety

Note that if you are driving into Hoboken allow extra time to find parking.  There is a paid parking lot right next to Trinity (entrance on 3rd street).  You can also park at Lincoln Harbor just north of Hoboken and bike down along the waterfront (about 15 - 20 minutes depending on how fast you ride).

We go at a casual pace (7 - 10 MPH). There are a few areas where we need to ride on the street. Most of the ride is along the waterfront and in Liberty State Park.

Below are pics of where we will be meeting.

-Mike
results.name: Bike Ride from Hoboken to Liberty State Park

results.description:
Speaker: Jone Johnson Lewis, Leader

Details: In most languages, some version of “How are you?” is a common social greeting. We mostly treat it as just a mantra exchanged, and only with close friends, if then, do we treat it seriously.  RYSEC Leader Jone Johnson Lewis will reflect on why this is such a common custom, and what we might find if we took that question more seriously with more people.

About the Speaker: Jone Johnson Lewis is the clergy Leader of the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture. Jone has been an Ethical Culture Leader since 1991, serving Ethical Societies in Chicago, Northern Virginia and Brooklyn. She's currently the President of the National Council of Leaders and a member of the American Ethical Union's Membership Committee.


For more information: http://www.rysec.org/event/how-are-you/?instance_id=2703 


Sunday programs are held at 11:00 AM at the Riverdale-Yonkers Society for Ethical Culture. For more information, please visit our website: <a>http://www.rysec.org </a>;
results.how_to_find_us: Directions on website or call the office during the week.
results.name: How Are You? (Taking That Question Seriously)

venue.name: Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County

group.name: The Ethical Culture Society of Bergen County

results.description:
Our Speaker will be:

Nelson Denis is an attorney, writer, film director, and former New York State Assemblyman. His new book is based on recently declassified FBI files, congressional testimony, oral histories, personal interviews and eyewitness accounts. It covers the Puerto Rican Nationalist Party Revolts of the 1950s, a series of coordinated armed protests for the independence of Puerto Rico led by the president of the Puerto Rican Nationalist Party, Don Pedro Albizu Campos.

The book also documents how the U.S. Army bombarded two towns and deployed thousands of troops in order to stop the uprising – the only time in history that the U.S. government intentionally bombed U.S. citizens.

results.description:
Early Riser on Sunday Mornings? Love Movies & Discussing Them?  Do You Enjoy the Warmth,Support & Potential of Community?  Enjoy Paying only Half Price for In-Theater Movies?  Then feel free to attend our Sunday morning movie meetups.

We meet every Sunday morning at approx. 10:30 for Cinema & Discussion-$ 8 per movie- Village East Cinema- (2nd Ave btwn 11th & 12th ) Occasionally we will go instead around the corner to Loews at 66 3rd Ave-depending on whats playing. (There are also foreign films & documentaries)- After the movie we go to a Coffee shop to discuss the movie. I can be reached by text at[masked] or [masked]. 

The movie choices will be posted in the comments section Thursday morning for a group vote

Thank You,

Sal Blech

results.description:
Serving hot meals anywhere from 900 to 1,098 homeless men and women at this veteran soup kitchen in Chelsea. The last time I was there we did a little over a thousand. Help many faces in New York who will be happy to receive a meal.

Our Volunteer project Event

When: Sunday

Sunday: (11:45 a.m. - 3:45 p.m)

Please feel free to contact me if running late or can not make it! (718)[masked]

Welcome Table Community Dining Program:
Open every Sunday, a day when most soup kitchens in NYC are closed, the Welcome Table serves between[masked] hot meals each week. We strive to go beyond food distribution by providing our guests with assistance in obtaining entitlement benefits through the NYU Law School’s REACH program, free adjustments by Chiropractors for Humanity, voter registration drives.

When arriving:

Please make your way to the cafeteria, downstairs.

Please sign in as you come in. Please text me if running late (please arrive on time).

PLEASE NOTE: IF VOLUNTEERING WE NEED EVERYONE TO STAY THE ENTIRE SESSION (UNTIL 3:30 PM)

https://youtu.be/axGqgMM6ZDA

 


Emails to confirm attendance will be sent closer to the event

Thank you

Olisa Fowlin

I will send an email prior to the event with my cellphone number and contact.
results.name: St. Francis Xavier Soup Kitchen in Chelsea

group.name: Evenings & Weekends in New York City

results.description:
Folks, 
Inviting volunteers to join me at the St Xaviers Church Welcome Kitchen on Sunday to serve over 1000 meals to the poor and homeless provided by St Xaviers Pantry.

This is based on the values that we would treat everyone equal,trustworthy, with dignity without any discrimination. We also want to be socially inclusive, including everyone with their preferences, culture and celebrate diversity. We will serve vegetarian dishes. The Soup Kitchen is dependent on volunteers to help work towards sustaining these values our community. If you are interested in being a volunteer, rsvp through this page. You don't have to be particularly skillful, we believe that if you have the passion, that's all that's needed :)


Soup Kitchen provides the aprons, gloves, hairnets. (one can wear their own baseball hat). Long hair need to be tied back unless it all fit in the hair net. We work with you, show you what to do. Please wear something comfortable.

Type of help could vary from coordinating the line, serving meals, Removing empty plates from the table or general helping out. 

Location -

 Church of St. Francis Xavier (Basement Hall)

46 W. 16th Street (Between 6th and 5th Avenue), New York, NY

Time -

11:30 - 3:30 ( You are required to stay till the end)

I will put my number on the meetup wall once we get close to the date. Members might get different responsibilities but will try to work as a group.

results.description:
Winner stays, guys!

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=3XviR7esUvo

And just in case anyone needs a refresher, some guidance from Coach Ted Lasso.

http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=6KeG_i8CWE8

No refunds or credits will be offered. Please be 100% sure that you can attend before you RSVP.

Please have a fun, positive, and supportive attitude. Pass the ball to your teammates and have a good time. NO rough playing, slide tackling, or screaming at others will be tolerated. You'll be removed from the game immediately.

No cleats are allowed. Let's do our part to preserve the field. Turf or running shoes are recommended.

Always bring a *dark and white* t-shirt

Be on time.

Teams are broken out ahead of each game based on skill level. Beginner, intermediate, and advanced players are all encouraged to join.

We play THREE, 25-30 minute games with a brief break between each game.

How to get to Queens West Sportsfield.

Queens West Sportsfield is located at:

5th Street between 47th Avenue & 46th Road, Long Island City


From Grand Central it's 3 minutes/1 stop on 7 Train. Take 7 train to Vernon Jackson.

From Queensboro it's 3 minutes/3 stops on 7 Train. Take 7 train to Vernon Jackson.
results.name: It's soccer for fun day!

results.description:
Are you looking to BALANCE your training & stretching?

Are you looking for RELIEF from joint wear, tightness, pain, and/or discomfort?

Looking for a complementary training to ENHANCE your overall well being on and off the track?

Would you like to RELEASE physical, mental and emotional tensions?

About Yin Yang Yoga...A typical Yoga class is ‘Yang’ in style and focuses on active heating and muscular contraction - by combining it with ‘Yin’, a more passive, nourishing, and cooling practice, this uniquely designed class WILL balance your whole being in training!

Why For Runners/Athletes? - Lengthening and releasing effect from repetitive movements (overuse) on sheets of connective tissue (fascia) can overtime shorten and tighten in ingrained patterns around muscles. This can make one more prone to having injuries, abnormal posture, and inefficiency, as well as asymmetrical weakening. By targeting selected and rotated key areas in weekly Yin Yang Yoga class, one can better release tension, move with ease, and benefit from improved posture and injury prevention.

The Yin Yang Yoga for Runners class begins with series of held Yin floor postures to open the meridian channels/chakras, or the subtle pathways of the body. While surrendering into the edge of each pose for 2-5 minutes, students are guided in the cultivation of observance and breath, as they experience release of connective tissues and the stagnant energy around the hips, thighs, and lower back. Awareness is guided to sensations in the body that can be grounding and powerful experience of the NOW. The Yang or moving practice allows students to integrate the newly released energy, joint spaces for circulation, and flexibility, into active strengthening postures and movement sequences. Freedom of breath, alignment, and mental clarity will be elicited deeply during, after the class, and into one's training.

After our INTRO CLASS ON 9/10: "Jennifer is an awesome instructor. Her sessions are informative and her teaching style is patient, clear and inspires me to attain increased fitness. I look forward to attending her class. The very next day I was able to push through my usual 3-4 miles to complete a 6 mile run." Sandra

AND another student reported achieving best time running a 18 mile course...


**10 Classes Only - Join weekly for maximum benefits and donate suggested $15 per class for this this performance enhancing class not offered anywhere else in NYC!


PLEASE RSVP "YES" only if you will make it to class (or update), as space is limited to 15 -20, and bring a mat if you have one.

See you and/or would you please pass this limited opportunity on? Thank you!

Namaste, Jennifer, RYT-500hr
